Award.AwardTitle: Experimental study of the flow behavior of garnet at high pressures: implications for the rheology of subducted lithosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal focuses on investigating the strength of earth materials at extreme pressure-temperature conditions in order to provide the solid basis that is necessary to model geodynamic activities associated with plate tectonics. The results of this proposed study are important not only to a broad spectrum of the geophysics community but also to energy sciences since, in the latter, understanding geophysical properties and processes is critical to managing improved production of Earth's energy resources and safe disposal of energy related waste. Furthermore, this research will establish new experimental techniques, and the results will be integrated into the academic curriculum and will provide an important learning experience for students.

Specifically, this proposed study is designed to develop a fundamental understanding of the mechanical properties of garnet at high pressures. Since garnet is an important mineral in Earth's subducting plates and the transition zone, the strength of garnet plays an important role in governing the dynamics of such tectonically active regions. Despite its importance, to date the mechanical properties of garnet have been poorly constrained, mainly because the working pressure for conventional apparatuses is too low to reach the stability field for garnet at high temperatures. This shortcoming limits enormously the advance of our understanding of the dynamic behavior of the subducted lithosphere. This proposed study describes research that utilizes a new generation of high-pressure equipment, the deformation-DIA apparatus, an advanced mechanical testing system capable of deforming geo-materials at much higher pressures and temperatures than previously possible. With this apparatus, it is now achievable to investigate the physical properties of garnet at the high pressure-temperature conditions appropriate to subduction zones. Three specific tasks are proposed to be undertaken. First, we will quantify the effect of pressure on the high-temperature strength of garnet. Second, we will investigate the influence of chemical environment (e.g., water) on the flow behavior of garnet at high temperatures and pressures. Third, we will determine the difference in strength between olivine and garnet, the two of the most abundant minerals in Earth's upper mantle. In general, the results of this research will contribute to the solution of geodynamic problems by providing a foundation of scientific understanding of earth materials at extreme conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this project is to quantify the rheological behavior of garnet under simulated mantle conditions (e.g., high temperatures, high pressures, and the presence of fluid phases) and the associated geophysical implications for the rheological properties of subducted lithospheric mantle. Experiments were carried out at high temperatures (1223 ≤ T ≤ 1423 K) and high pressures (1.6 ≤ P ≤ 5.6 GPa) using a D-DIA apparatus. Samples synthesized from a natural polycrystalline garnet were deformed under water-saturated conditions with water supplied by the dehydration of talc during the experiments. A power law fit of our experimental results on the creep of garnet samples demonstrates strong dependencies of strain rate on water fugacity with an exponent of r = 1 and on pressure with an activation volume of V* = 28×10-6 m3/mol. Importantly, under water-saturated conditions the water content of deformed garnet samples measured by infrared spectroscopy increases with increasing pressure and water fugacity up to an average value of ~21000 H/106Si at ~3.0 GPa and then decreases with increasing pressure and water fugacity down to ~3000 H/106Si at 5.6 GPa. The flow law for garnet quantified in this study provides an important constraint on the strength of the subducted lithosphere. For a water-enriched environment, the viscosity of a garnet-rich layer will be low above the shallow upper mantle because the water content in garnet increases with increasing pressure at relatively low pressures. However, as pressure increases, the viscosity will be high in Earth’s deeper interior because the direct effect of pressure, which acts to decrease creep rate, outweighs the indirect effect water, which acts to enhance creep rate.

The project has trained graduate students and post-docs in the art and science of high pressure research, providing them an exciting platform to develop research interests as well as skills in experimental earth science research. To date, this project has led the productions of two doctoral theses, two articles published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, and eight published meeting abstracts. A few more peer-reviewed manuscripts and one more doctoral thesis are anticipated in the near future.

In this project, deformation experiments were carried out using x-ray testing techniques, in which differential stress in a deforming sample and deformation of the sample were monitored in-situ using synchrotron x-ray diffraction and radiography, respectively. To investigate the influence of water on the rheological properties of garnet, we developed hydrous cells to conduct experiments under water-saturated conditions.  The experimental techniques developed in this study forms a solid basis for carrying out future experimental work which is crucial to advance experimental studies in the field of Earth sciences. Furthermore, these techniques will have also direct impact on the fields of high-pressure physics and materials engineering, providing novel techniques on testing materials at extreme conditions.
